posts.name: Josh Smith
posts.cooked:
Took a stab at making some onshape 3D print files for organizing our 3mm belts. Based heavily off of 118’s belt wall. Figure I’d share the work if anyone was looking for something similar. Haven’t tested yet but they’re on the printer now!

Sign in to Onshape, the #1 fastest growing CAD system in the world with over 4 million users.

posts.name: Ryan Stockton
posts.cooked: For others wanting to make your own version of the belt wall here is the spreadsheet I used to determine the width of each “peg” should be based on belt length. We used 1/2" plywood for this but you could modify it for whatever thickness you wish.

posts.name: Alex Kalinin
posts.cooked: I saw this and thought I’d take a crack at it. I made a completely parametrized version here using some configurable belts I made previously.

posts.name: Phil Szymanowski
posts.cooked:
Very cool! Make sure your mounting holes move when the part gets bigger as well.

image 1541×600 54.2 KB

image 1541×600 54.2 KB

image 1541×600 54.2 KB

posts.name: Alex Kalinin
posts.cooked: The idea was that the holes stay spaced correctly for mounting on hole pattern. If they were on either end, the spacing would be completely inconsistent, and you wouldn’t be able to just drill a couple pairs of 1/2 in spaced holes in some plywood and mount it. Just my personal preference on how I like mounting stuff. This isn’t a high-stress application, so the long lever arm isn’t that much of an issue either.

posts.name: Phil Szymanowski
posts.cooked: You can use the round() function in the distance input for those holes to still match up to your hole pattern.

posts.name: Alex Kalinin
posts.cooked: It would mess with the text, and I’m personally a fan of the consistency. I’ll make it an option though.
